intro: Cornus alba var. occidentalis, commonly known as the Western dogwood, is a deciduous shrub native to the western United States. It features showy, white to pink bracts that appear in late spring, often mistaken for flowers. The plant has opposite, simple, ovate leaves that are typically red or purple in the fall, adding ornamental value. It thrives in partial shade to full sun and prefers well-drained soil. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to attract pollinators.
